Award.AwardTitle: Building the Capacity for Community-engaged STEM Teacher Preparation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the NSF Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program, this project aims to serve the national interest in high quality STEM teaching by building capacity to prepare highly-qualified middle and high school STEM teachers for high-need Texas schools. Through collaborations between Texas A&M University, Corpus Christi, and the West Oso Independent School District, the project will develop an infrastructure for recruiting, preparing, and supporting new middle school and high school STEM teachers. The project will engage community partners in designing and delivering meaningful activities for teacher candidates, thus strengthening connections between schools and their communities. Long-term goals of this project include increasing student achievement in STEM fields and helping to address the national shortage of highly-qualified STEM teachers.

The project will begin by conducting an assessment to define teacher shortage areas and to prioritize teacher training needs. The results of the assessment will inform the design of a new licensure program for middle and high school STEM teachers. STEM faculty, Education faculty, school personnel, and community partners collaborate to develop a community-engaged teacher preparation curriculum. This work will strengthen the partnerships among these groups. The resulting new courses, field experiences, and community mentoring activities will be pilot tested and assessed. The project will also develop and pilot test strategies for recruiting talented STEM undergraduates from diverse groups into teaching careers. The NSF Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program supports talented STEM undergraduate majors and professionals to become K-12 mathematics and science teachers in high-need school districts and in-service teachers to become STEM master teachers. It also supports research on the persistence, retention, and effectiveness of K-12 teachers in high-need school districts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report: NSF Noyce Capacity Building Project # 1852790

Texas A&M University Corpus Christi has been using resources from the Noyce Capacity Building Grant titled Noyce STEM INSPIRES (Infusing Social Programs in Residential Education Scholars) by continuing to develop its mission and vision. Our mission and vision relies on the development of intentional and meaningful relationships with our partner school district, West Oso Independent School District (WOISD) and including INSPIRES community mentors that live and work there. These community mentors are primarily African American WOISD residents who well represent the ethnicity of the students in their schools.  The PIs have continued to meet with the community mentors over a 2 year period as we built momentum toward the submission of the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarships and Stipends (S&S) Track I grant that was submitted in August 2020 and funded in March of 2021. We have been using Capacity Building funding to build relationships and articulation agreements with Del Mar Community College in Corpus Christi Texas as we developed recruitment plans for future Noyce STEM scholars and post-secondary teachers in the Noyce S&S Track I grant. Our community mentors have been helping the Noyce PIs to develop the courageous conversations and culturally relevant curriculum that will be implemented in the Noyce S&S grant. Their oral history and lived experiences in the low income WOISD community have been shared and will ultimately be a part of the experience of our future Noyce preservice teachers, that is, our Noyce Scholars. The capacity building grant continued to help us develop these important relationships that are at the crux of our STEM INSPIRES initiative - social justice through STEM.

The Noyce Capacity Building Grant for Noyce STEM INSPIRES has provided the resources and intentional space to develop its mission and vision through the development of relationships with our partner school district, West Oso Independent School District (WOISD), a high needs school district, and our community mentors that live and work there. Our community mentors are helping to provide the culturally relevant tools that help REACH children before our Noyce Scholars can begin actually teaching them. STEM subjects require high levels of critical thinking. Implementing state mandated curriculum is not enough. We will be helping the WOISD inservice teachers to reform curriculum that increases self-efficacy in 7-12 STEM content and incorporate a community -engaged teacher preparation program model at Texas A&M University Corpus Christi that can be replicated outside of WOISD. The Capacity Building grant helped us to recruit several Faculty Fellows ? college faculty in math, chemistry, biology and physics who will be incorporating and valuing the funds of knowledge community experts bring to the education table. As preservice teacher educators, we are not able to connect with minority youth culture, community, and home without building relationships prior to teaching ? transforming all participants in the process. Eventually, this effort may extend into other disciplines such as history, language arts, social studies, etc. Many of the components we are using (community-engagement) are not STEM centric. We look forward to extending our program into other subjects, making the program broader, and increasing institutionalization by WOISD.

A major result of the Capacity Building grant is that Noyce INSPIRES is making an impact by raising awareness of the importance in building relationships in our schools and communities. This will impact science and technology by increasing critical thinking, creating scientists and policymakers who are aware of cultural similarities and differences, and empowering and encouraging students. We will, through our community mentors, be identifying tools for content mastery, tools for critical thinking, tools for action and social change, tools for personal reflection and tools for awareness of multicultural group dynamics. We will be focusing on teaching with efforts at working toward social justice in STEM classrooms. Noyce Scholars may elect to teach at WOISD thereby improving the performance, skills, or attitudes of members of underrepresented groups that will improve their access to or retention in research, teaching, or other related professions.

In summary, the Noyce Capacity Building Grant did just that ? it helped the investigators, faculty, community mentors and college faculty build the capacity needed in creating the Noyce S&S grant that was subsequently funded. The resources were needed to travel, fund working dinners, provide professional development in the social justice arena, and supplies such as books related to social justice and student-centered pedagogy in STEM. We look forward to putting our plans into action, creating socially-just, well prepared STEM teachers who will be welcomed into a diverse work force and will understand the importance of building meaningful relationships.
